docs.abstract: Trade officials approved the company’s request to remove tariffs on the Apple Watch.
docs.snippet: Trade officials approved the company’s request to remove tariffs on the Apple Watch.
docs.lead_paragraph: OAKLAND, Calif. — U.S. trade officials removed tariffs on the Apple Watch, the latest Apple device to avoid the United States-China trade war that had once looked like a dire threat to the company’s business.

headline.main: Trump Administration Gives Apple More Tariff Relief

docs.abstract: The household staple has consistently been out of stock during the coronavirus outbreak. Manufacturers may not be willing to increase supplies.
docs.snippet: The household staple has consistently been out of stock during the coronavirus outbreak. Manufacturers may not be willing to increase supplies.
docs.lead_paragraph: If there’s one image that captures the panic seeping through the United States this week, it might be the empty store shelves where toilet paper usually sits.

headline.main: Is There Really a Toilet Paper Shortage?
headline.print_headline: Is There Really a Toilet Paper Shortage?

byline.original: By Michael Corkery and Sapna Maheshwari

docs.abstract: The internet is a pretty scary place right now. Here are some ways to make it better.
docs.snippet: The internet is a pretty scary place right now. Here are some ways to make it better.
docs.lead_paragraph: Each week, we review the week’s news, offering analysis about the most important developments in the tech industry.

headline.main: The Week in Tech: How to Stop Coronavirus ‘Doomsurfing’
headline.print_headline: Doomsurfing Is Not Good for You

docs.abstract: Financial markets have been on a roller coaster as investors react to the spread of the coronavirus and efforts to protect the economy.
docs.snippet: Financial markets have been on a roller coaster as investors react to the spread of the coronavirus and efforts to protect the economy.
docs.lead_paragraph: Starbucks informed staff that it would close its cafes in the United States in response to the coronavirus crisis, though it will remain open for delivery and drive-through customers, the company said in an emailed statement on Friday.

headline.main: Starbucks Is Closing Cafes and Boeing Says Executives Will Forgo Pay
headline.print_headline: Indexes Tumble After a Tumultuous Week

docs.abstract: The troubled California utility is agreeing to limit payouts to shareholders to satisfy Gov. Gavin Newsom in its effort to emerge from bankruptcy and qualify for a state wildfire fund.
docs.snippet: The troubled California utility is agreeing to limit payouts to shareholders to satisfy Gov. Gavin Newsom in its effort to emerge from bankruptcy and qualify for a state wildfire fund.
docs.lead_paragraph: Pacific Gas & Electric reached an agreement Friday with Gov. Gavin Newsom of California in which it pledged billions of dollars to help wildfire victims, improve safety and make other changes, resolving the biggest obstacles to the company’s plan to come out of bankruptcy.

headline.main: PG&E Reaches Agreement With Governor, Clearing Bankruptcy Hurdle

byline.original: By Ivan Penn and Peter Eavis

docs.abstract: The I.R.S. stepped up its crackdown on abuses of “captive insurance” in January, but the vehicle may prove its worth during the coronavirus outbreak.
docs.snippet: The I.R.S. stepped up its crackdown on abuses of “captive insurance” in January, but the vehicle may prove its worth during the coronavirus outbreak.
docs.lead_paragraph: A type of private insurance that is used by wealthy business owners to cover unlikely risks and that has been challenged by the Internal Revenue Service is proving to be beneficial as the coronavirus pandemic shuts down local economies.

headline.main: Once Scrutinized, an Insurance Product Becomes a Crisis Lifeline
headline.print_headline: Often Seen as Tax Dodge, Now a Crisis Lifeline

docs.abstract: Natural-gas companies operating in the state were looking shaky before the coronavirus hit. Local economies are now at risk.
docs.snippet: Natural-gas companies operating in the state were looking shaky before the coronavirus hit. Local economies are now at risk.
docs.lead_paragraph: CARMICHAELS, Pa. — The last time the global economy was in free fall, an economic savior showed up in southwestern Pennsylvania. Energy companies, which had discovered a way to get at the state’s vast natural-gas reserves, invested billions of dollars in the region, cushioning the blow of the Great Recession.

headline.main: Fracking Once Lifted Pennsylvania. Now It Could Be a Drag.

docs.abstract: From setting a clear agenda to testing your tech setup, here’s how to make video calls more tolerable for you and your colleagues.
docs.snippet: From setting a clear agenda to testing your tech setup, here’s how to make video calls more tolerable for you and your colleagues.
docs.lead_paragraph: In the age of coronavirus, many of us have transformed overnight from office workers into telecommuters. And we are increasingly relying on videoconferencing apps like Zoom and FaceTime to correspond with our peers.

headline.main: The Dos and Don’ts of Online Video Meetings

docs.abstract: The Kremlin-backed Internet Research Agency, which interfered in the 2016 election, is using different methods to hide itself better.
docs.snippet: The Kremlin-backed Internet Research Agency, which interfered in the 2016 election, is using different methods to hide itself better.
docs.lead_paragraph: Ahead of November’s election, American intelligence officials and others are on high alert for mischief from Russia’s Internet Research Agency.

headline.main: How Russia’s Troll Farm Is Changing Tactics Before the Fall Election
headline.print_headline: Russian Troll Farm, Before and After

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates

docs.abstract: Legions of seasonal workers from Eastern Europe who harvest crops from Spain to Sweden can’t get in, forcing a rapid rethink of how to secure food at Europe’s farms.
docs.snippet: Legions of seasonal workers from Eastern Europe who harvest crops from Spain to Sweden can’t get in, forcing a rapid rethink of how to secure food at Europe’s farms.
docs.lead_paragraph: PARIS — When Europe tightened its borders to prevent the spread of the coronavirus, France’s biggest farmers sounded an alarm: The workers they rely on from other countries to harvest much of the nation’s food could no longer make the trip.

headline.main: Migrant Farmworkers Whose Harvests Feed Europe Are Blocked at Borders

byline.original: By Liz Alderman, Melissa Eddy and Amie Tsang
